text:
So I'm delighted to be here. I'm really looking forward
to having more conversations with folks today.

I'm doing a bit of a different
talk, more kind of at a meta level, kind of about doing
research papers in computing,

particularly in HCI
and computer vision. And what I'm hoping you might
come away from this talk

as maybe being a
little bit inspired to try experimenting in how
you do research papers, how

you write them.  John Van Maanen, who's a
prominent organizational science

scholar-- he's done a lot of wonderful
ethnographies of companies-- wrote a really great paper
about style as theory.

And he says, "We cultivate
and teach a writing style of nonstyle that values
limited metaphor, simplicity

and a formal, if not
mathematical precision. Much of our writing is washed
by a thick spray of claimed

objectivity, since artful
delights in forms are seen by many if not most writers
and readers in the field

to interfere with the
presentation of was actually there in a given social world."

So Van Maanen goes on to
describe certain ways of what we typically look for
in research papers,

and particularly, I would
say, in qualitative papers, clarity of argument. You want to elegant,
keep to the essentials,

unadorned, showing deep
analysis, spare in some points. And especially in HCI,
I think we think about,

are we doing the right
theoretical claims? Or maybe, do we have
implications for designs?

Perhaps some
sensitizing concepts.  So I want to just
talk about like,

what does a qualitative
paper look on HCI? And rather than try to
critique someone else's paper, I'll just look at my own papers.

And I think this maybe is-- I wouldn't say it's an
exemplar, but maybe it's a common style that
wouldn't be out of the norms

in writing qualitative papers. So I think everyone knows the
basic structure, or many of you

know there's an abstract
introduction, related work, talking about methods.

And then, in the
Finding sections, typically they come from maybe
from some grounded theory

analysis coding,
doing some memoing, and then that forms the
genesis of certain sections.

You can describe them as themes. So this was a
study on Irish pubs and the use of
smart phones, using

interviews and observations. And so one of the
findings from the coding is what the team was
about, how people lose

authentic banter in the pub. And the mobile phone
presents that back and forth,

authentic banter. And then we have a
quote here talking about the ebb and
flow of conversations,

and how even though there's
a fact they're discussing, they can look up on smartphone.

They're saying, I'd rather
we not look at the smartphone and interrupt the flow, and
keep the conversation going.

And then if you have people
with phones and without phones, then it creates the
have-nots and have phones.

And then people get left out. So this is kind of one
of Finding sections. And then at the end, you
might have a discussion,

Design Implication section. So here, we're thinking
about, well, the Irish pub

is a third space, but it's
becoming a surveilled space with the smartphone. And so how might we limit the
surveilling in this space?

Reconfiguring the pub
space might be one design implications, making mobile
only areas, smartphone limiters.

Maybe we're thinking
about if you're doing trivia games in the
pubs, which are popular, make the answers more
ambiguous, not just

have one answer, et cetera. So this is one way,
I think, not too

uncommon about doing
reporting and disseminating qualitative research. And so maybe we can
shift gears and think

about what's a different way
to talk about qualitative work. And so I want to switch to
a book written by Kathleen

Stewart, an anthropologist. She wrote a book called
Ordinary Affects that talks about experiences of
American culture broadly.

And in her
introduction, she says, "The book tries to slow the
quick jump to representational

thinking and evaluative critique
long enough to find ways of approaching the complex and
uncertain objects that fascinate

because they literally hit
us or exert a pull on us." So stick with me here.

"My effort is to find something
to say about ordinary affects by performing some of the
intensity and texture that makes

them habitable and animate. Ordinary affects is
written as an assemblage

of disparate scenes. Each scene begins anew the
approach to the ordinary from

an angle set off by
the scene's affects." So Kathleen Stewart adopts
an affect theory approach,

and through her
writing, she's trying to capture some of that
affect and emotion. And the fact that
you can't always--

when you have a feeling, you
can't always pinpoint it. And sometimes, you can even
label the feeling you're having.

Sometimes, the feeling comes,
ends with some uncertainty. It comes with a shock. These are aspects that
are hazy that she wants

to convey through written word. So I'll give you an example of
one of the scenes in the book.

So the book has a
preface, but then it has a number of scenes
of varying lengths.

And some of them are couple
pages or two paragraphs. Some of them are
just one paragraph. This one is called PMS Powered.

It begins, "Ordinary scenes
can tempt the passerby with the promise of a
story let out of the bag.

Matter can shimmer with
undetermined potential and the weight of
received meaning. One day she's walking through
the gated community of Irvine,

California, where, as some who
can't afford to live there, say, all the trash cans
sit on doilies,

and all the weeds
grow in perfect rows." I did my PHD, so I
can attest to that.

"She comes across a late-model,
fire-engine-red Ford sedan parked at the
curb on a cul-de-sac.

Sprawled across the driver's
doors are the words PMS Powered. A snazzy car with an
in-your-face attitude,

it back talks the social
snickering of PMS jokes. She imagines the car
driving around town

as the moving scene of
an attitude adjustment. But when she walks
around the car, she sees that both tires
on the side are missing.

The car is actually listing on
one hastily placed jack left either by thieves in a
hurry or by the harried car

owner in the middle
of a compound problem. Now the car becomes
another kind of thing. More complicated.

Perched on the unpredictable or
unimagined edge of the ordinary, it takes on the full charge of
potential's two twisted poles--

up or down, one
thing or another. It sparks in the tension
between drudgery and routine--

the barely holding on--
and the flash of event."

Here's another excerpt, just
two sentences called Hardwired. "We take our cues so directly
from circulating forces that

the term 'hardwired' has
become shorthand for the state of things. Little undulations are felt as
pleasures and Warning signs,

as intoxications and
repetitions in daily routine." So I think everyone will
have a different reaction

to these scenes. But just think about
what sort of reaction had-- does it convey affect?

I think just keep those
in the back of your mind. So after she
published this book,

I think it caused
a bit of a stir. And so there was sort of
a "Author Meets Critics"

article published, where
some scholars wrote about their reaction to the work, and
then Kathleen Stewart replied

back. So one person said,
"It is a book that works best when you immerse
yourself in it, when you let

it affect you rather than
trying to pin it down and force it to make sense. I keep returning to it
as an effective rendering

of ordinary life and
common American culture. Attending to affect dispels
the insistence for intellectual

comprehension and allows the
visceral to come to its own ordinary surfacing, unburdened
by the weight of theoretical

representation." So I think these
encapsulate notions

that her writing is tentative,
speculative, and relies on you, as a reader, to do
some heavy lifting.

So Kathleen Stewart said
that she wrote the book to incite new forms of
writing and reading,

new approaches to
analytic objects, and new forms of
attention, attachment to the intensities and
sensibilities now taking

place in the various
situations of the ordinary. So the book is an
experiment in ethnography.

So I really liked this book. Lilly was the one who
first recommended it to me, so I looked it over
to think about how

to write qualitative work,
especially with emotions. So what happened
was there was a book

being made about
the HCI outdoors with Scott McCrickard, Michael
Jones, and Tim Stelter.

And they invited me
to write a chapter. So I thought maybe I can
try to write something in this style for
an HCI audience.

It's an invited chapter, so I
can experiment a little bit. Less of a risk to do it as well.

So because I've been recently
interested in rural computing, and I was trying to understand
what does it mean to be rural--

and is it rural just a place? Is it a feeling? And this chapter captures some
of my thoughts about that.

And part of it is
because I could draw from my own experience. I grew up in San
Martin, California. Anyone know where that is,
San Martin, California?

OK. Yeah. So you just drive about
an hour, 15 minutes

maybe, with no traffic
past Morgan Hill, and it's in between
Morgan Hill and Gilroy.

And so it's a small,
unincorporated city. And I don't know when
I was growing up there, but it's considered
a rural area.

So then I wrote some scenes
in Kathleen Stewart's style talking about effective
infrastructures, for example.

So in my family's backyard,
they do have a barn, but when they bought the place,
they did not put animals in it.

They used as a car garage. And then I also wrote
an excerpt talking about the internet
infrastructure there.

So I'll just read
some small part of it. So, "Every time he goes
home, he expects it.

Web pages load at
a crawling pace, so much so that he notices
the order in which texts

and images download and display,
starting from the upper left. His dad shows him flyers from
Viasat, exclaiming service alert

for speeds up to 10 times faster
than typical DSL at his address. The flyer has a photo of country
homes with spacious land,

lush trees, and cute sheds,
all bathed in rays of sunlight. Presumably, Viasat is the
beacon of hope for the rural.

He sees that its satellite
service, $50 for the first three months, but increase
it to 470 afterwards.

Sigh. What a rip off. He feels trapped, and the
companies know it too, the desperation in the air."

And then I also posted
a picture of a-- if you drive by a road
by my parents house,

there's a telephone post or
whatever with all these signs. Many of them stapled on about
getting new internet access.

I also wrote about
my experiences in Indiana talking about
doing field work with hunters.

So I did some studies
about the use of technology by hunters and issues of
fairness and technology.

And this one depicts a scene
where I went to Starbucks to meet an informant at a town
that has a history with KKK

and racism, actually. But in that
interaction, I talked about ordering at
Starbucks, and I asked

the person what he wanted. I said, my treat. And then Peter looked
up and was overwhelmed by coffee choices and lingo,
tall, grande, flat, white, et

cetera. Scratching his head, Peter
asked if they had hot chocolate. He was bemused. That's me.

That Peter don't know how
to order at Starbucks. But then looking back, he
wondered why he was bemused.

He's ashamed. When he first started
drinking coffee, he was confused by his choices. Of course, Starbucks
is its own country

with strange words like
frappuccino and venti. He should look at his own
consumerist Generation X

commodification, having
become a citizen of Starbucks International. So this is kind of talking
about my own biases

when talking to some of
the rural populations. So I wrote this chapter
with a whole bunch

of these different scenes, and I
didn't put a Discussion section.

I had a very short intro. And then what the editors
did, which I appreciated,

was that they sent the draft
chapters to their students and their classes, like
CS students, and ask them,

OK, it's your job to-- you
guys are presenting it. And then you're going to have
some people in the audience.

You have to have you
have to lead a discussion about this chapter. So these are some of the
reactions from the students.

They compiled it for me. They said, "First, it's
fun, but it gets tiresome. The chapter with its
length and organization

took several readings
to make sense. It was after a half dozen reads
and one convincing team member

that the presenters decided to
own this new form of writing and dive into it. One commented that the writing
grew in us, but like fungus."

Some students, the ones
who didn't have to lead it, they are pleased
that they just had to read some vignettes
as standalone text,

while having to connect
them to other vignettes and without the aim of drawing
some meaningful conclusions or discernment.

"The presenters
went through stages of dismissal, frustration,
infuriation to persuasion.

And then some of the students
wanted some kind of handholding might have gone the readers
farther down the trail.

Perhaps something even less than
handholding would have sufficed. Just watching a friend jump the
ditch can reassure one that is

possible and worthwhile." So as a result of
this feedback, I

did write a section about the
motivation of writing this work, talking about ethnography in HCI
spiel I gave at the beginning.

And then I talked about
how I might interpret it as thinking about realities as
something more to be performed

and everywhere in the bodily
experiences about that, and then also encouraging the
reader to come up with their own interpretation,
not necessarily my own.

So we did try a
more radical format adopting Kathleen Stewart's,
seeing what the CS

students' reactions were. And then I took some
of that feedback. And then at that
same time, the paper

that Michael was referring to. Lily, and Amanda, and I-- Amanda Lazar-- we're thinking
about external critique,

specifically, and
how that affects tech workers in companies. So we want to know how
things like tech lash

affected the lives
of tech workers inside their
organizations and outside.

And what are the emotions
that they're feeling? And so we thought that trying to
use Kathleen Stewart's writing

style might be
appropriate for this because it really is
about the emotions. And we want to also
foreground each story.

So I think attention
I often feel when writing qualitative
work is that, to some extent,

you have to reduce
what people are saying. You're going to have to
choose quotes judiciously

to make your point, and you
lose some of the narrative that they're telling you. And you're weaving into
your own narrative.

So we want to really
foreground their own stories without necessarily
inserting ourselves in too much in the text.

So we did a semi-structured
interviews with tech workers about external
critique they received.

They sketched the experience. And then we also asked
them to modify the sketch on how they expected. They would like the
experience to change.

So this person is
talking, I think, to his brother
and saying, how do you feel about
destroying democracy?

And then he wanted to correct
it and say, hey, I heard about this, about your company.

What's that about? He rather that be
the discussion. Once I got the
empirical data from that

using traditional methods of
inquiry in qualitative work, then we converted
them to scenes, just
like Kathleen Stewart.  So this is a long test.

I won't go through
the whole thing, but this is the bare text
of the interview itself and describes the scene in the
subway where the person has

their headphones on. And they look over. They see someone moving
their mouth towards you,

and they're saying something. And they look kind of angry. So I say, excuse me. And then they say,
and you hear it.

And it blindsides you
at first because it's like, I don't even know you. So many things are
going through my head.

First, I don't know you. Two, what are you talking about? And then, three,
once you realize what they're
talking about, which

is a critique of their company,
it's like, OK, that's why. I'm trying to piece
together a puzzle in a split

couple of seconds on
the subway before I even respond because I'm
trying to figure out who this person is, what they
want, where they're coming from.

And then once you
figure out, it's like, I just put my
headphones back on, and I turned away
and kept going.

And my inner thought is,
here we go again this type of thought because I've dealt
with it at Koala, pseudonym

of the company. And what I mean by
this is misinformation. We talk about people
feeling the need.

When they feel like they
can be masked and disguised or they can't see, you
can't point them out

because they're being backed
up or validated by the masses. So it's like groupthink. And we talked about that there's
a feeling the need to critique

someone just because they're
wearing the company logo. You don't really know
their affiliation.

It's almost easier for me to
yell at a human than to yell at an idea of a company.

So based on that, that's
just one excerpt part of that interview. But we took other excerpts from
the interview as well, where

the participant talked
about their own background and identity of first-generation
Caribbean immigrant

and some of the racism
that they faced as well, and how they grew a
thicker skin as a result,

And then we described it in
terms of Dakota's viewpoint-- "is on the subway,
minding his business,

listening to music
with his headphones. A first-generation
Caribbean immigrant, he had grown up hypervisible
as only person of color

in his town. But this is a new thing. He turns to see something
out corners eye. It seethes with anger.

He tries to ignore it, but
hovers about buzzing at him. Their mouths move,
grumbling for attention, speaking in Peanuts-like
dialect-- wah, wah-- angrily.

Pulling out the headphones,
he says, excuse me. Then they say it,
and he realizes. That scarlet letter
drew them in.

Like many tech workers,
Dakota got company schwag-- a bag proudly displaying
Koala's emblem.

He calls it a Scarlet Letter. So many things are
spinning through his head. He's trying to piece
together a puzzle in a split

couple of seconds before
he can even respond. Who is this person? What do they want?

Where are they coming from? Nonetheless, he's numbed to
the deja vu of hypervisibility. Here we go again.

Once he figures out what
they're going to do, he turns away and keeps going. Later, he took a black marker
and actually scratched out

the bag's logo. It wasn't enough. He removed the stitches. You could still see that. And then he eventually
used another bag."

So that comes from another
part of the interview as well. So that's the conversion
of this to a scene,

and we did it all
as a group together. And in the paper, also, we
were very careful to describe

how we design the paper itself. And these are minute
details, but it's

different from Kathleen
Stewart's writing a little bit because we did actually
put in subsections

and different
themes, and organize the quotes in different ways. But we still want to be sure
to separate the researcher's

voice from the scenes that
the participants describe.

And then we used a
little symbol there. It's called a
fleuron, apparently.

That's an old-style thing that's
used in books as a separator from the researchers
voices and the scenes.

And so we talked a lot
about how to symbolize this. We thought, can we add text
that says, OK, now we're

going to switch to the
person, the participant? But we didn't want
the additional text

to remove away from
the story itself. And we thought the
symbolic meaning would be better to transition.

So the way the writing work
was-- so we had the transcripts. We did do the
traditional qualitative

coding of the
qualitative research, and then those kind
of serve, if you like,

as sensitizing concepts
as we develop the scenes. And then from the scenes, we
also mapped out a narrative

connecting some scenes together
and grouping them together. And then we did member checking. We sent back all the scenes
back to the participants

and the narrative to
ask them to verify what they thought about that. I think there's only
one correction that

was more a factual change. And then we did have a
Discussion section about one way

to interpret the
results, which is talking about the emotional
habitus of tech work.

So the scenes we're
saying represent overall. What is the prevailing way to
feel and act in tech companies?

And this prevailing way
to act will orient you to certain political
action in actions.

It doesn't control
you like a robot, though it definitely orients
you and suggests what you can and cannot do in a company.

And one of the things
that often suggests is that you should try
to be rational, have technological hope, do
constructive criticisms only,

and embrace technological
solutionism. Other kind of feelings which
are more unusual in companies

were not really in
this emotional habitus. To feel anger or sadness or fear
in a tech company was unusual.

So it kind of closed off
certain actions, which could happen with the workers. But the tech lash
opened things up,

where workers now did feel
these feelings of companies that used to be a big
deal to work at,

but now people were
critiquing them. And so because
they couldn't feel the way they wanted
to these companies,

they would seek
out other spaces, like maybe like the tech workers
coalition or online forums.

And this diagram
from the cover slide, it represents like how
we did the narrative, the messiness in it.

So at some point, we actually
cut up all the scenes in paper and scanned it. And then we used a Miro board.

And we're playing around
with the narrative and seeing what would convey the
thoughts the best over there.

So just a few things
about this paper. Initially, I wanted to have
no Discussion section at all,

like we thought, but then I was
talking to my collaborators. But they're saying, OK,
you just can't do that.

You need to give a
little handholding. So we did that, but we
tried to make it clear that was one interpretation,
and we invited readers

to come up with their own kind
of Discussion section based on the scenes.

I'm not sure if that was
entirely successful or not. So I talked a little bit about
pushing boundaries of paper.

So I talked about
just an example of what is HCI call work
right now and then trying to think about adopting
a more radical style,

adopting Kathleen
Stewart's way of using empirical work with a chapter.

And then, finally, maybe being
a little bit more conservative compared to the HCI outdoors
chapter and publishing at CSCW

here. So I want to now move,
make a little shift of doing the same things about
looking at computer vision

papers. But I think, first, we want to
talk a little bit about what is a computer vision paper, too.

So we've done some
recent research looking into doing
a media archeology approach of the CVPR papers.

So this was worked on with
Sam Goree, Gabe Appleby, and David Crandall.

And so we went through all the
CVPR papers from 2013, 2021.

And then Sam actually did
interviews with veteran computer vision researchers
at the conference

as well to ask them about
changes in the paper format for computer vision. And the basic premise
is you think papers,

they are designed social and
cultural interface created by disciplines, and
creating scientific truth.

So what's changing? And what does that change signal
overall about the discipline?

So I'm just going
to talk about a few of the high-level findings. More of the point
is to just talk about what is a computer
vision paper now.

A lot of it is about
advertising, we argue. So teaser images are a big
part of computer vision papers.

So you can see in this plot here
about the percentage of papers

that have at least
one teaser figure has been rising astronomically. And then we also--

teaser is just like
showing oftentimes many different
algorithms and models,

attempting to solve
the same problem, but they depict it in
such a way, obviously, that their approach
will be the best here.

So here's wireframe detection. And then there's is at the end
ours, which is doing the best.

And then you can
try an analogy of-- Sam found a good example
of bounty paper towels.

And then they do
a demonstration. Here's one that breaks
up easily, and here's one that's strong and still
has its structure.

Another part that's a big part
about computer vision papers is the tables of results.

Measuring contribution. Tables of results
are a big part of it. I think it's tempting
to just think

of them as textual content,
but the effect on the paper, we argue, is partly visual.

So tables visually
represent state of the art, often with respect to
top-one accuracy on ImageNet,

test sets for image
classification or for average precision on
test sets for object detection.

And then the best results-- usually, the authors aren't
bold in these tables inevitably. So the design feature is
essentially for readability

because these large
tables are hard to read, difficult to interpret it. And it should be noted that
computer vision papers were not

always about tables of results. So in the '80s or '90s, a
lot of the papers relied

on mathematical arguments based
on pinhole camera geometry. They had no quant results.

Empirical results,
evaluation included at all was primarily qualitative,
or they would just show you,

hey, we made this image, or
these are the things detected. It looks pretty good. And they just showed
the image there.

Showing some samples. And so this represents a
transition of computer vision

from an applied math discipline
to a quantitative empirical one. So as vision became reliant
on empirical evaluation,

it adopted tables of results. And that results table
is also comes from,

I think, borrowed from runtime
benchmarking computer graphics as a discipline as
well over there.

So as evaluation
benchmarks became established for vision
problems, tables

grew in size and importance. And competition on benchmarks
is an organizing principle

of the discipline, arguably. So I think this quote is great. It talks about-- if it's
an established benchmark,

there's somebody
who has the lead, just like you would have in
a classic video game arcade

machine. You have to have your
initials with the top score. That's what they're doing,
and that's what's frustrating.

And then you can see the
fraction of CVPR papers with figures and
tables over time.

And the average number
of figures in tables s paper over time as
well is increasing.

And another thing is, like,
I think right now, some of us cling on to paper, but the PDF
paper, especially in vision,

is now viewed as a
screen-based format. Some of the older
researchers talked about

that they enjoy the photocopying
from the proceedings. I remember when I used
to do that sometimes.

And then there's a
preciousness to the paper that you have there. And you might go back to it. But now, it's a
screen-based format.

And I think this is
reflected in the PDF format using the vector images.

So a lot of the papers
will have images like this, which,
if you print it out, are completely illegible.

And even at a normal
scale on the monitor, if you show the whole
paper, is hard to read. So you have to zoom into
the image to actually see

the details, to look at them. So this is an
example of one image.

And then here are
some other examples of highly
information-dense figures.

And these help bend
the conference limits.

You can fit the images in. They're visually appealing. And if you want to see
details, you zoom in.

That's the PDF format there. So the overall argument,
we make this about what

is a computer vision paper. It's a lot about attention and
reflexive attention economy.

Contributions of paper
reduced to its exchange value in terms of the
attention it generates,

and authors leverage
early attention to increase prestige
values of papers. So this, obviously, is like
posting papers on archive,

getting feedback there, putting
it in front of more eyes, and increasing chances to
reach the right audience

through social media posts. And all these attention made
the interviews in the paper,

talk about that these lead
to more citations, job opportunities, students,
and even grants.

So I encourage you to look
at the paper in more detail. There's a more extended
discussion also of the effects

of archive as well. So that's the standard of the
computer vision papers right

now, and it's about
grabbing attention. It has certain
hallmarks in its style.

And so I want to
shift on saying, OK, one thing we want to do--

again, looking at
emotions, again, was saying, can we publish
a purely qualitative paper

in computer vision? That was one of the challenges
I was talking to David one day. And then because we
have been talking

about what is the emotional
impact of the explosive growth of computer vision. So to do this work, we
actually collected 56 stories

from the computer
vision community, and this was in the
height of the pandemic.

So we used a writing prompt
in a Google Doc format. So the participants would
be guided to a Google Doc

and on top would say,
please write down a nonfiction story, at
least two paragraphs,

involving yourself as
the main character. Stories should depict
the real concrete event,

involve computer vision
or machine learning, involve recent changes in
those disciplines, should

have an emotional
impact, be memorable, and should be relatively
self-contained. So it doesn't need some kind
of other external document

to understand. And then we also gave
some helpful hints.

Maybe like, how do you
write a good story? Maybe have a dramatic element. You can experiment with
your writing style.

You can put dialogue. You can try to think
of a progressive plot establishing, setting
conflict, rising to a climax,

and wrapping up with loose ends. So in a way, we try to
emulate a little bit

of the semi-structured
